channel.title: Visual Studio is busy
channel.description:
This is pissing me off beyond the limit. It just started happening today. I'm trying to build a solution in Visual Studio, and it freezes for about 5-10 minutes, and gives me a little pop-up saying "Visual Studio is busy" -- OH ARE YOU NOW? I can build C# projects, F# projects, Visual Basic projects, and asp.NET projects just fine. But when I want to build a C/C++ project, it has to pull this shit. And this wasn't happening before today.
I went ahead and totally formatted my hard drive -- for my own reasons - then I reinstalled an academically-provided version of Visual Studio Professional, and went ahead and tried again. Guess what happens, it does it again...
I've searched the net everywhere for a solution, but I haven't looked here yet, so I'm just wondering if any of you have ever had this problem before, and maybe know a way to fix the problem. It also seems there are MANY other people with this same problem.

item.title: Visual Studio is busy
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

I have VS2010 Professional, It has never not worked.

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Studio is busy
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:8, topic:382455”][quote author=pure2ownage link=topic=478249.msg3500535#msg3500535 date=1297700685]

You could just use the free and open source gcc (mingw) compiler for windows, that is what I compile all my windows programs with.

the better option.
[/quote]dis

Visual Studio is gay, I kept getting ‘registry access not allowed’ although I had changed access rights to “allow for all” (in short), So now you must uninstall this shit.

Your incompetence to troubleshoot the problem doesn’t mean there’s something wrong with Visual Studio. I use VS2010 Ultimate, excellent IDE, never had any problems.[/quote]I had it to, every help site which I have visited done the steps and it ‘worked’ (although there was a bunch of flaming in the comments).

Read full topic

Your incompetence to troubleshoot the problem doesn’t mean there’s something wrong with Visual Studio. I use VS2010 Ultimate, excellent IDE, never had any problems.

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Studio is busy
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Since you switched, I’ve heard Code::Blocks is a good IDE, I’ve never used it myself though. I generally just use a text editor for C/C++ development.

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Studio is busy
item.dc:creator: @Liquid_Magic Liquid Magic
item.description:
@Liquid_Magic wrote:

[quote=“k0 twin, post:5, topic:382455”][quote author=pure2ownage link=topic=478249.msg3500535#msg3500535 date=1297700685]

You could just use the free and open source gcc (mingw) compiler for windows, that is what I compile all my windows programs with.

the better option.
[/quote]dis

Visual Studio is gay, I kept getting ‘registry access not allowed’ although I had changed access rights to “allow for all” (in short), So now you must uninstall this shit.

I don’t know what you all are on about, visual studio is just fine. I have 2010 professional and it works like a charm.

My only suggestion is to keep searching the web for a solution, I’ve never had/seen a problem like that before.[/quote]
I agree. It’s a really nice, useful tool, and after all the time that I’ve been using it, it would be hard to switch just because of some annoying bug (or possibly an internal problem ^_^). Thanks for the help everyone, I’ll just have to search more.

Edit: Using MinGW for the time being…

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Studio is busy
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

No idea as to what would be causing it, have you tried compiling a different program? Perhaps the compiler or pre-processor are getting stuck in an infinite loop of some sort.

You could just use the free and open source gcc (mingw) compiler for windows, that is what I compile all my windows programs with.

Read full topic
